Every muscle in his body screamed in protest, a chorus of deep aches and sharp, stinging cuts. Pip, his scruffy coat matted with grime, soot, and the black paste of their camouflage, had no such complaints. He rolled and wriggled in the grass, a small, ecstatic vortex of relief, sneezing as blades of grass tickled his nose. For the dog, the nightmare was over, the door slammed shut, the bad place left behind. For Flinch, the memories were already taking root, thorny vines of fire and fear coiling around his heart.

They had to move. The first hint of dawn was touching the eastern sky, turning the deep indigo to a bruised purple. The cemetery was a good crack, but it was not their crack. Flinch pushed himself to his feet with a groan, his joints grinding in protest. They were in the old St. Nicholas churchyard, a place he knew from his wider-ranging scavenging trips in his youth. It was a city of the dead, a peaceful, slumbering mirror to the city of the living that surrounded it. They moved through the leaning headstones and past the stone angels whose faces had been worn smooth by a century of wind and rain. Flinch felt a kinship with the forgotten names etched into the stone, the lives lived and ended, their stories now reduced to a few weathered letters. He, too, felt like a secret history, a story no one would ever know.

The journey back to Hove was a slow, painful limp through the waking world. Flinch kept to the shadows of the back alleys, his senses stretched taut, but his fear had changed. He was no longer just looking for humans. He was listening. Listening for the sound of sirens, for the panicked shouts of emergency crews, for any sign that the city had felt the death of the monster beneath its feet. But there was nothing. A solitary milk float hummed its electric tune down a deserted street. A paperboy on a bicycle flung a tightly rolled newspaper onto a doorstep, the soft thud impossibly loud in the quiet air. The city was sleeping peacefully, utterly oblivious. The catastrophic collapse, the goblin civil war that had raged and ended in fire and ruin, had been so deep, so contained within the hidden world, that not a single ripple had reached the surface. The thought was both a profound relief and a source of deep, unsettling loneliness. He was a ghost who had fought a war in a haunted house that no one else even knew existed.

His mind replayed the events in a frantic, disjointed loop: the hungry, pale eyes of Old Man Silt; the locket, his beautiful secret, lying on the greasy stone; the sheer, hellish scale of the Resonator; the grinding, shattering sound of his sabotaged gear tearing the machine apart. He touched the scorch mark on his cheek, the raw scrapes on his knees. It was real. He hadn't dreamed it. He had walked into the heart of the fire and, somehow, he had walked out again, leaving nothing but ash behind him. Grolnok, his army, his terrible key—all of it was buried under a mountain of Brighton station. He had committed an act of mass destruction, an act of war, and the world had not even blinked. He was a hero no one would thank and a killer no one would hunt, a paradox that left him feeling hollowed out, as if he himself were now just another empty crack in the world.

When they finally reached the familiar stretch of the Hove promenade, the sea was a sheet of polished slate under the growing light. The cream-coloured buildings stood serene and untouched, their windows dark and blank. Flinch looked at them, these elegant homes of the sun-walkers, and for the first time, he felt a strange, protective ownership. He saw not just their careless bounty, but their incredible, blissful fragility. He had seen the chalk bones of their world and understood how easily they could be broken. The tide was pulling back its grey blanket once more, leaving the shingle damp and littered with new secrets of the night. It was the beginning of his hour, the quiet hinge, but the simple thrill of the hunt felt like a distant country he could never visit again. He guided Pip to the forgotten iron hatch, his movements stiff and automatic. His fingers, trembling with exhaustion, worked the complex series of levers and bolts. The familiar, satisfying clicks of his lock, his own small symphony of security, was the most beautiful sound he had ever heard. With a final, heavy clunk, the way was open, and he and Pip slipped inside, sealing their tiny, peaceful world off from the vast, unknowing one outside.

Inside the den, the silence was a physical presence, a thick, smothering blanket that pressed in on him. He had spent his life cultivating this quiet, hoarding it like his most precious treasure, but now it felt unnatural, a void where the roaring and the grinding ought to be. His own harsh breathing was an unwelcome intrusion, and the frantic, happy panting of Pip, who was deliriously sniffing every familiar corner of their home, sounded like a shout in a library. Flinch stood frozen just inside the sealed hatch, his hand still resting on the locking mechanism, his knuckles white. He was a creature of the cracks, and for the first time in his life, he felt that the most dangerous place in the world was the tiny, sealed space he had just locked himself into. The enemy was no longer outside. It was in him, a phantom vibration in his bones and a searing afterimage of purple fire behind his eyes.

Slowly, as if moving through deep water, he forced his body into motion. First, the dog. He poured clean water, a luxury scavenged from an abandoned allotment’s rain barrel, into a chipped ceramic bowl. Pip, delirious with thirst, lapped it up noisily. Flinch took a clean rag and gently began to wipe the grime and soot from the dog’s matted coat, his movements methodical and grounding. The simple, repetitive action of caring for his friend was an anchor in the swirling chaos of his mind. Once Pip was passably clean and had curled up on his sleeping pallet with a great, exhausted sigh, Flinch turned to himself. He caught a glimpse of his reflection in a shard of mirror he used for intricate work, and he flinched away from the creature looking back at him. The face was gaunt, the eyes wide and haunted, the skin a mask of soot streaked with sweat and something that looked horribly like blood. A dark, angry scorch mark painted his left cheekbone, a permanent brand from Grolnok’s furnace. He looked like one of the pier-goblins, a creature of violence and darkness, and the realisation sent a wave of revulsion through him. He scrubbed at his skin until it was raw, trying to wash away not just the filth, but the memory of what he had become in that cavern.

The cleaning revealed the extent of the damage. His knees and elbows were raw, pulpy messes, and a dozen smaller cuts and gashes crisscrossed his arms and legs. He tended to them with a scavenger’s practicality, using a foul-smelling antiseptic solution decanted into a small glass bottle and clean strips of cloth torn from a discarded linen shirt. The sharp, chemical sting of the antiseptic was a welcome pain, a clean and honest sensation that helped to chase away the deeper, more complicated aches in his soul. Each wound he dressed was a testament, a paragraph in the terrible story of the night. As he worked, his gaze drifted to the loose floorboard. He saw not just the empty space where the gear had been, but the other void beside it, the one left by the silver locket. He had traded beauty for truth, and the truth had flayed him raw, leaving him with nothing but the ugly, painful evidence of his survival. He had won a war no one knew had been fought, and his victory felt indistinguishable from a profound and utter defeat.

Exhaustion finally claimed him, pulling him down like a tide. He did not so much lie down as collapse onto his pallet beside Pip, his body giving up the fight to remain upright. But sleep offered no sanctuary. His dreams were a lightless cavern where the only sound was the grinding of a million unoiled gears, a sound that vibrated up from the floor and into his teeth, his bones, his very skull. He was climbing a vast, skeletal machine that pulsed with a malevolent purple light, and every handhold was slick with oil and humming with a current that threatened to stop his heart. He saw the faces of the goblins below, their features twisting from triumph to terror as the world began to shake itself apart. He felt the crushing weight of the earth, the final, thunderous roar of the collapse, and he woke with a strangled cry, his heart hammering against his ribs, the smell of ozone and hot metal thick in his nostrils. Pip whined and nudged his face, a warm and living comfort in the suffocating darkness of the den, but Flinch could not shake the feeling that he was still down there, buried a mile beneath the sleeping city, with the ghosts of Grolnok's army.

Days bled into one another in a grey, timeless fog. Flinch did not leave the den. He ate from his small stash of preserved foods—tins of sardines, hard biscuits, dried fruit—without tasting any of it. He mended the rips in his jacket with fingers that felt clumsy and disconnected, his needlework, usually a source of quiet pride, now a frustrating, meaningless chore. The silence he had once cherished became a torment, amplifying the ringing in his ears and giving free reign to the looping memories of the cavern. He found himself staring at his collections, the ordered chaos of his life’s work, with a stranger’s eyes. The rows of sea-glass were just broken bits of human rubbish. The intricate cityscape of radio parts was a fragile, pointless toy. They were the relics of a smaller, more innocent goblin, a creature who had believed the world was something to be curated and collected, not something to be fought for and bled on. The urge to go outside became a gnawing, physical need, not for scavenging, but for reassurance. He had to see the sky. He had to feel the salt spray on his face. He had to know, with his own eyes, that the world he had almost lost was still there.

When he finally unbarred the hatch, it was with a sense of grim duty, not a thrill of anticipation. The air that greeted him was cool and damp, the familiar air of a goblin's hour. The low mist clung to the water, and the gulls cried their mournful echo. Everything was exactly as it should be, and yet everything was different. He crept along the tideline, Pip trotting beside him, but his eyes were not scanning the shingle for gleamers or fixings. He was scanning the horizon, the base of the sea wall, the dark, dripping underbelly of the pier, searching for threats, for signs of change, for anything that might suggest he hadn't truly won. His senses, honed by a lifetime of quiet observation, were now cranked to a painful, paranoid pitch. Every wave that broke on the shore sounded like falling rock. Every shadow held the shape of a crouching goblin. The joy was gone, replaced by a vigilant, weary patrol. He was no longer a collector; he was a sentry, guarding a sleeping city that didn't know it needed him.

Pip, unburdened by such existential dread, was still a partner in grime. A series of excited yaps announced a discovery. Flinch’s heart seized, his mind instantly flashing to black-iron and malevolent runes. He scurried over, his hand already reaching for the heavy spanner he had tucked into his belt, a tool he now viewed as a club. But Pip was not digging at a piece of a terrible machine. He was nosing at something tangled in a thick, dark brown mass of seaweed at the high-tide line. It was a rectangle of oilcloth, the kind used by goblin fishermen and drain-crawlers to keep their possessions dry, tough and waterproofed with pungent fish-grease. It must have been washed out of a burst sewer outflow during the chaos of the collapse. Flinch’s first instinct was to leave it, to walk away from any remnant of that other world. But curiosity, a goblin's most persistent curse, was too strong. With the tip of his boot, he nudged the package free of the seaweed. It was heavier than it looked. He knelt, his fingers, still trembling slightly, fumbling with the knotted cord that held it shut. He pulled back the oily flap. It was not a weapon. It was a book, small and thick, its leather cover swollen and warped by its time in the water, but its pages protected by the waterproof wrapping. He opened it carefully. It was filled with a tight, elegant, spidery script, a form of scholarly goblin writing he had only ever seen in fragments. It was academic, precise, entirely different from the brutal, angular runes of the pier-goblins. Then he saw the frontispiece. Drawn with an artist's delicate hand on the first page, occupying the space where a title would be, was a single, perfect image. It was a silver locket, engraved with swirling leaves, catching an unseen light. A cold shock, sharp and clear as a winter morning, shot through Flinch. This was not just any book. This was Silt's.

The drawing was not a memory or a passing likeness; it was a perfect, heartbreaking copy. Flinch’s fingers, stained with grime and his own dried blood, traced the elegant swirl of the engraved leaves, a ghostly echo of the gesture he had made countless times with the real thing. It was Silt’s book. The realisation struck him not with the force of a blow, but with the silent, chilling finality of a closing door. The old mud-lark, the archivist of the deep dark, had kept a record of his price. And the only way this book, Silt’s most precious possession, could be here, tangled in the night’s seaweed, was if the cataclysm Flinch had unleashed had been far more widespread than he had imagined. The collapse of the vaults had not been a surgical strike. It had been an earthquake, its shockwaves ripping through the city’s hidden veins, rupturing ancient tunnels and forgotten chambers, turning Silt’s carefully barricaded burrow into a watery tomb and flushing his secrets out into the indifferent sea.

A new and terrible weight settled in Flinch’s gut, a cold, specific guilt that was far heavier than the anonymous destruction of Grolnok's army. He had not just killed warriors who had chosen their side; he had killed a librarian. He had destroyed an archive. The image of Silt’s burrow, with its shelves of meticulously labelled jars and its maps drawn on cured leather, being torn apart by a black torrent of mud and filth, was a violation that struck at the core of Flinch's own soul. For a collector to destroy a collection, for a finder to be the cause of so much being lost—it was a unique and unforgivable sin. He had snuffed out a vast and irreplaceable repository of knowledge, all to save a world that neither knew nor cared that it had been in peril. Silt’s last, rasping words, 'What you do with it is your own funeral,' now seemed like a curse that had come to fruition, just not for the goblin it was aimed at.

He should have thrown it back. The scavenger’s instinct for self-preservation, the part of him that had survived by avoiding trouble, screamed at him to hurl the waterlogged book as far as he could into the grey water and walk away. This was not a gleamer or a fixing; it was a burden, a legacy of secrets too heavy for one goblin to carry. To keep it was to invite the ghosts of the underbelly into his carefully curated life, to become the custodian of a truth he had never wanted. But a deeper, more fundamental part of his nature, the obsessive collector, the creature who built cities from junk and found solace in the categorisation of the lost, could not let it go. This was the ultimate find, a treasure not of matter, but of meaning. It was Silt’s life’s work, a complete and unabridged chronicle of the world beneath the world. To throw it away would be a second, and perhaps greater, act of destruction. With a grim finality, his fingers tightened on the damp leather cover. The book was his now.

With a furtive glance up and down the deserted shoreline, he hastily wrapped the book back in its oilcloth sheath, the pungent smell of fish-grease a strangely comforting scent of goblin ingenuity. He tucked the heavy, awkward package into his scavenging bag, where it sat like a block of ice against his hip. The return journey to his den was a new kind of flight. He was no longer just a sentry guarding against a defeated enemy; he was now a fugitive carrying forbidden knowledge. Every gust of wind sounded like a pursuing footstep, every shadow seemed to hold a pale, watching eye. He imagined other goblins, drain-dwellers and sewer-crawlers who had known of Silt, wondering what had become of the old mud-lark and his legendary archive. What would they do if they knew that a solitary scavenger from Hove was now in possession of the master text? The thought spurred him on, and he scurried along the base of the sea wall, his desire for the safety and secrecy of his lockable hatch more desperate than ever before.

Inside, with the complex mechanism bolted and the candle casting its familiar, dancing shadows, the den was no longer a tomb but a study, a scriptorium. Flinch did not collapse onto his pallet. He moved with a grim, scholarly purpose. He cleared his small workbench, carefully setting aside the delicate components of a defunct music box he had been tinkering with. He wiped the surface clean with a rag, then lit a second candle stub, the increased light pushing back the shadows, creating a small, intense island of illumination. Pip, sensing the change in his master from weary sentinel to focused obsessive, hopped onto the battered armchair cushion and watched with his head cocked, a silent, furry observer. Flinch unwrapped the book one more time, laying the oilcloth flat and placing the swollen leather volume in the centre of the light. He took a deep breath, the air tasting of dust, wax, and the faint, briny scent of the book’s journey, and prepared to enter the mind of Old Man Silt.

The first few pages were a testament to Silt’s obsessive nature. There were painstakingly detailed maps, not of the major storm drains that Flinch knew, but of the forgotten capillaries of the system: Victorian pneumatic postal tubes, sealed-off plague-era sewer lines, even natural aquifers that ran beneath the city. There were notes on the chemical composition of runoff from various industrial sites, cross-referenced with observed mutations in the local fungus populations. It was a staggering work of natural and unnatural history. He turned a page and found a detailed genealogy of the pier-goblins, tracing their lineage back to a belligerent clan chief named Skabrus Jaw-breaker, complete with notes on their violent tendencies and their crude, brutish approach to metalworking. It was a cold, anthropological dissection of his enemies, written with the detached air of a scholar studying a particularly unpleasant insect.

He kept turning, his fingers moving faster, a strange hunger driving him on. He was looking for something, though he did not know what. Then he found it. A section titled 'The Scattered Clans and Solitaries.' His breath caught in his throat. He saw a reference to the Underbellow clan and a brief, cutting biography of his own grandfather, Shale, described as 'an idealist, fatally optimistic about co-existence, who led his kin from the power of the warrens into the ignominy of the cracks.' It was a dismissive, almost contemptuous summary of the philosophy Flinch had lived by his entire life. He read on, his eyes scanning the spidery script, and then a single entry, dated only a few months ago, made his blood turn to ice. It was short, precise, and utterly devastating. 'Hove Shingle. Flinch Underbellow. Grandson of Shale. A proficient finder, specializing in discarded human tech. Possesses a high degree of mechanical aptitude. Unaligned. Sentimental.' Flinch stared at the last word, the candlelight seeming to dim around him. Sentimental. Silt hadn’t just known about the locket through whispers. He had known *him*. He had been catalogued, observed, and assessed like one of the city's fungi. His accidental stumble into this war was no accident at all. He had been a known piece on the board, a piece Silt had moved with a single, perfectly calculated trade. And as Flinch sat there, the weight of the book in his hands, he realised a chilling truth: he hadn't just found Silt's archive; he had inherited it. He was the new archivist, whether he wanted to be or not.

The word hung in the air, a single, damning piece of data in an ocean of it. *Sentimental.* It was not an observation; it was a diagnosis. Silt had looked into Flinch’s soul from a distance and found the flaw, the exploitable weakness in his code. The old mud-lark hadn’t just traded for a trinket; he had leveraged Flinch’s entire nature. He had known Flinch would treasure the locket beyond its material worth. He had known Flinch would risk everything for the slobbery allegiance of a stray dog. He had known that this quiet, solitary scavenger, who lived by the rule of never being seen, had a core of softness that could be prodded into action. Flinch closed the book with a sharp snap, the sound unnaturally loud in the silent den. The feeling that washed over him was not guilt or grief, but a cold, sharp, clarifying rage. He hadn't been a hapless victim of circumstance. He had been a tool, selected from a catalogue and expertly wielded by a master manipulator who was now dust and memory, leaving Flinch to carry the weight of his machinations.

The rage burned hot for a few moments, then flickered and died, leaving behind only the cold ash of exhaustion. What was the use of being angry at a dead goblin? It was as pointless as shouting at the tide. He was alone with the consequences, and the most significant consequence of all was lying on his workbench, a heavy, leather-bound summary of every secret he had spent his life avoiding. He opened it again, no longer as a curious finder, but as its designated keeper, its prisoner. The book was a key, but a key that opened a thousand other cages, each one containing a problem, a threat, or a sorrow that was now, somehow, his responsibility. His finger traced the spidery script, and he began to read not for answers, but for the scope of his inheritance.

He learned of the Clay-Fingers, a dwindling clan of goblin potters who lived in the muddy banks of the River Adur, their magic tied to the shaping of the earth, their existence a constant, quiet struggle against the encroaching damp. He read of the Rust-Gnawers, a nomadic tribe of tinkers who travelled the railway lines at night, their religion a strange worship of the 'Iron Serpent'—the freight trains that thundered through the dark—believing them to be divine beasts. He read of solitaries, like himself but different: a goblin named Moss-Mane who lived in the canopy of Stanmer Great Wood and could reputedly speak the language of crows; a grim, silent fisher-goblin who haunted the wrecks off the coast, trading drowned things for scraps of metal. The book was a secret census of his own kind, a vast and lonely tapestry of scattered, hidden lives. He was not unique. He was just one more entry in a ledger of the lost.

The days that followed were a descent into obsession. The rhythm of his life, once dictated by the rising and falling of the tide, was now governed by the turning of a page. He forgot to eat. He let the candles burn down to sputtering puddles of wax, lighting new ones without a thought. His collection, his life's work, gathered a fine layer of dust. The world outside his iron hatch ceased to exist. His world was now the rustle of dry vellum, the smell of old ink and fish-grease, and the spidery script that mapped the hidden arteries of the world. Pip, sensing the shift, became his shadow, his furry, worried conscience. The dog would nudge the book with his nose, trying to insert himself between his master and the object of his fixation. He would bring Flinch a scavenged, slobbery tennis ball, dropping it hopefully at his feet, his tail giving a few tentative wags, an invitation to a game that belonged to a forgotten world. Flinch would just stare at the page, his mind a thousand miles away, in a muddy riverbank or a dark forest, and Pip would eventually give up, slumping to the floor with a heavy, disappointed sigh.

It was a sound, an incongruous noise from the outside world, that finally broke the spell. It wasn't loud. It was a soft, scraping sound, a dry scuff against the outer face of his iron hatch. It was a goblin sound. Flinch froze, his head snapping up from the book, his body instantly rigid. Pip was already on his feet, a low, barely audible growl rumbling deep in his chest. Flinch held his breath, straining to hear over the frantic hammering of his own heart. The scraping came again, followed by silence. It was not the clumsy fumbling of a human, nor the random scratching of an animal. It was deliberate. A signal. A message. Flinch sat there for what felt like an hour, every nerve screaming, until the profound silence of the pre-dawn world reasserted itself. Whoever had been there was gone. He waited longer still, until the first grey light of the goblin's hour began to filter through a tiny, high-up crack in his den’s wall. Only then did he dare to move.

With a stealth he hadn’t used since the night in the vaults, he crept to the hatch. He did not open it. Instead, he used a tiny viewing hole he had drilled for just such a purpose, a pinprick of vision disguised as a rust spot. He peered through, his eye taking in the familiar, empty stretch of the lower promenade. There was no one there. But on the dark, rust-pitted surface of his iron door, etched with a sharp flint or a piece of glass, was a single, fresh symbol. It was a simple, elegant spiral, a rune he had seen only once before, in the faint, ancient scratches on the walls of the storm drains. The goblin rune for 'safe path'. But this was no guide. It was a calling card. It meant one thing, and one thing only: *I know you are in here*. His den, his sanctuary, his fortress of solitude, had been compromised. His quiet crack in the world had been found.

A new kind of fear, cold and sharp, cut through the fog of his obsessive study. He had assumed that with Grolnok's army annihilated, he was safe. He had been a fool. The underworld was a web, and he had just seen the first tremor travel down a strand that led directly to his door. Silt's death had not gone unnoticed. His disappearance had created a power vacuum, and now the hunt for his legacy, for his book, had begun. Flinch looked from the chilling symbol on his door to the book lying open on his workbench. He could not stay here. To remain was to wait for the next visitor, who might not be content to simply leave a mark. He had to run. But where? The world was full of cracks, but he had just learned that he was a known entity in all of them. He was no longer an anonymous scavenger; he was Flinch Underbellow, the sentimentalist, the accidental archivist, the goblin who held all the secrets. His gaze fell upon the book again, this time not as a scholar, but as a fugitive looking for an escape route. His eyes scanned the section on the Scattered Clans, his mind racing. He could not fight them. He could not hide from them. His only chance was to find someone who feared the secrets in his book as much as he did. His finger landed on an entry. The Clay-Fingers of the River Adur. Silt had described them as reclusive, ancient, and deeply suspicious of outsiders, their magic tied to the quiet, slow shaping of the earth. They were not warriors. They were potters. Menders. Like him. It was a long shot, a desperate gamble, but it was the only plan he had. He had to find them. He had to trade one secret for another, to offer them the knowledge of their own hidden world in exchange for a safe place to hide within it. He began to pack a bag, his movements no longer sluggish with despair, but sharp and purposeful. He was leaving his home. He was taking Slinch's archive with him, and with Pip at his side, he was going to walk off the edge of his own map.

The act of leaving was a quiet, brutal amputation. Flinch moved through his den not with the frantic energy of a fugitive, but with the grim, methodical grief of an executor settling the estate of his own life. The scavenging sack was small, a vessel woefully inadequate for the cargo of an entire existence. Silt’s book went in first, wrapped in its oilcloth sheath, its weight a solid, dense core of trouble around which everything else would now orbit. He added his multi-tool, a pouch of dried fish for Pip, and a tightly sealed tin of fresh water. Then he stood before his shelves, his museum of the discarded, his testament to a life of quiet obsession. The sea-glass, sorted by a decade of tides into a perfect spectrum of blues and greens. The intricate cityscape of radio parts, with its tiny wire-frame towers and capacitor-block buildings. These things were his soul, made tangible. He couldn’t take them. They would weigh him down, and where he was going, they would be meaningless. He ran his long fingers over a line of defunct wristwatches, each one stopped at a different, forgotten moment of human crisis. His own crisis was now, and there was no time. He selected one small, practical item: a coil of his finest scavenged wire, strong and pliable. It was a 'fixing', a symbol of his old self, a tool for a mender in a world that needed mending. He tucked it into a pocket. Then he turned his back on the rest, an act of will that felt like tearing his own skin.

Before he unbolted the hatch for the last time, he took one final look. The single candle flame he had lit guttered in a draft, casting long, dancing shadows that made the familiar space look alien and accusatory. It was no longer a sanctuary. The mark on the door had poisoned it, turned it into evidence, a scene of a crime waiting to be discovered. He saw it now as his pursuers would: a strange, obsessive nest filled with clues to the creature who lived here. Sentimental. The word echoed in the silence. He looked at Pip, who was watching him with an awful, knowing anxiety, his tail tucked low, his body a single, tense line. The dog understood that this was not just another walk. Flinch knelt, putting his forehead against Pip's. "It's just us now, boy," he whispered, his voice thick with an emotion he couldn't name. "Just us and the book." He gave the dog's scruff a firm, reassuring squeeze, then stood. With a deliberate movement, he extinguished the candle flame with his fingertips, plunging the den, and his entire former life, into absolute darkness.

Slipping out into the pre-dawn gloom was like being born into a world of ghosts. The familiar promenade was a pale, empty stage, and he felt horribly exposed, a single dark figure moving across a vast, empty canvas. The thrill of the goblin’s hour was gone, replaced by a cold, prickling paranoia. Every shadow seemed to stretch towards him, every distant sound was an approaching threat. He didn't head for the tideline. The beach was too open, too visible from the blank windows of the buildings above. Instead, he led Pip west, keeping to the deepest shadows at the base of the sea wall, moving towards the boundary where Hove's elegant stucco faded into the more industrial tangle of Shoreham Harbour. He was a fugitive now, and his path could no longer be the path of a scavenger. He was following a different map, an invisible overlay of forgotten rights-of-way and hidden goblin-tracks gleaned from the pages of Silt’s book.

The urban landscape frayed at the edges as they moved west. The grand promenade gave way to concrete sea defences, chain-link fences, and the sprawling, gritty infrastructure of the port. They passed silent stacks of shipping containers that cast monolithic shadows, and crept by slumbering fishing boats whose nets smelled of salt, diesel, and decay. This was a different kind of crack to live in, a place of hard edges and transient purpose. Flinch felt the shift in the air, in the very nature of the ground beneath his feet. The city was behind them. Ahead lay something else. According to Silt's map, his route would take him inland, following the path of a buried stream that fed into the harbour. They found the entrance where the book said it would be: a crumbling brick outfall, half-choked with mud and debris, hidden behind a rust-eaten gasometer. The smell that wafted out was thick with the rot of stagnant water and things long-drowned. Pip whined, balking at the dark, foul-smelling maw. Flinch tugged gently on his collar. "It's the only way, boy," he murmured. "The roads are for them. The deep ways are for us." He took a breath and plunged into the darkness, leaving the sight of the sea and the open sky behind.

The tunnel was tight and foul, but it was a path. Flinch followed the spidery annotations from the book, which he had committed to memory. 'Ignore the concrete tributary after two hundred paces—leads to a modern sump. Bear left at the junction marked by the triple-iron staple.' He moved with a new kind of confidence, the confidence of the map-holder. He was no longer just reacting; he was navigating. But the confidence was short-lived. In a wider section of the drain, where several tunnels converged, he saw it. A fresh mark, scratched hastily into the slime-coated brickwork. It was a crude, angular symbol: a broken spear. A sign used by the pier-goblins. It was a patrol marker, a sign of Grolnok's scattered, vengeful survivors. Flinch’s blood ran cold. They weren't just hunting for Silt's book; they were re-establishing their territory, their rage spreading through the underbelly like a disease. He quickly pulled Pip into a side alcove, his heart hammering. They waited, listening to the drip of water and the scuttling of unseen things. The hunters were out. His desperate flight had just become a race.

They emerged, hours later, blinking in the flat, grey light of a cloudy afternoon, from a narrow pipe half-hidden in a thicket of thorns and brambles. The air was different. The sharp, clean tang of salt was gone, replaced by a thick, loamy smell of mud, wet reeds, and green, growing things. Before them lay a vast, shifting landscape of brown and grey. The River Adur at low tide. A wide, lazy snake of water wound its way through acres of gleaming, treacherous mudflats, dissected by a thousand smaller channels. Great beds of reeds rustled in the breeze, their sound a dry, constant whisper. It was a place of immense, quiet emptiness, a landscape that felt older and more patient than the restless sea. According to Silt's notes, the Clay-Fingers lived 'where the fresh water weeps and the salt water sighs,' a poetic but frustratingly vague description. Flinch looked out at the vast, alien mudscape. His map had brought him to the edge of a new world. Now, he had to find the door.

The vast, grey emptiness of the mudflats was a new kind of prison. On the beach, the world was open, the sky a huge, liberating bowl. Here, the sky was just a lid on a flat, brown plate of a world, and the horizon felt like a closing wall rather than an invitation. The air, thick with the smell of decay and the low, iron tang of the mud, was a stark and unwelcome change from the clean, sharp scent of the sea. Flinch stood at the edge of the solid ground, the thorny brambles a barrier between the world he knew and this alien landscape. Pip whined, a low, unhappy sound, his paws sinking into the soft earth at the mud’s edge. He was a creature of firm ground, of city pavements and packed shingle, and this sucking, shifting terrain was an affront to his very nature. Flinch understood the feeling completely. His own skills felt useless here. There were no pockets to pick, no locks to jimmy, no discarded treasures to find. The mud held only its own secrets, ancient and indifferent to the fleeting troubles of a single, desperate goblin.

He forced his mind back to the book, to the mental map he had so painstakingly memorised. Silt’s poetic clue, 'where the fresh water weeps and the salt water sighs,' was his only compass. The sighing of the salt water was easy enough to understand; he could feel the subtle shift in the wind, the distant pressure of the turning tide. Soon, the sea would begin to reclaim these flats, a slow, silent flood that would erase all tracks and drown any creature foolish enough to be caught in its path. But the weeping of the fresh water was a more subtle challenge. It meant a spring, a seep, a place where the land itself bled into the river’s domain. It would be a source, a beginning, and Flinch knew, with a scavenger’s instinct for such things, that goblins tied to the earth would make their home near a source of life. He scanned the distant bank, a long, unbroken line of dull green and brown, looking for any anomaly, any break in the monotonous pattern.

The first step was a commitment. The mud closed around Flinch’s bare foot with a cold, obscene squelch, its grip surprisingly strong. He took another step, and then another, the mud sucking and pulling at him, trying to drag him down, to make him a permanent part of its featureless expanse. He quickly learned that the darkest, wettest patches were traps of deep, viscous ooze, while the lighter, cracked surfaces offered a more solid, if still treacherous, footing. Pip was, to Flinch’s surprise, a better navigator of this terrain than he was. The dog’s lighter weight and splayed paws allowed him to trot over surfaces that Flinch would sink into, and he seemed to have an instinct for the barely-visible ridges of sand and gravel that snaked through the mud like a hidden network of roads. Flinch fell into a new rhythm, letting the dog lead, his eyes fixed on Pip’s tail, that once-blurring metronome now a cautious, steady guide in a world that threatened to swallow him whole.

They moved across the flats in a slow, arduous trek, a pair of small, dark figures in a landscape of immense, uncaring scale. The cries of wading birds, curlews and oystercatchers, echoed around them, their long, lonely calls amplifying the profound emptiness of the place. The sun, a weak, watercolour smudge behind a uniform grey blanket of cloud, began its slow descent, and the light on the mudflats shifted, turning the wet surfaces to polished silver and the shadows in the channels to deep, forbidding purple. The tide was coming. Flinch could hear it now, a distant, sibilant whisper, the sigh of the sea breathing in. A cold knot of urgency tightened in his stomach. He had pictured a desperate flight from other goblins, not a race against the planet itself. This world didn't need malice to kill you; it just needed you to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.

It was Pip who found it. The dog stopped, his nose twitching, and veered off his gravel-ridge path towards a section of the riverbank where the reeds grew in a patch of unusually vibrant, almost luminous green. As Flinch followed, squelching through a shallow channel of water, he felt the change. The water here was colder, and when he dipped his fingers in and tasted it, the brackish tang of salt was gone, replaced by the clean, earthy taste of fresh water. He had found it. The bank wept here, a series of small, almost invisible springs seeping from the clay, nourishing the reeds and cutting a fresh, clear path through the salt-crusted mud. He scrambled up the low, slippery bank, his heart thudding with a mixture of hope and fear, and pushed his way through the thick curtain of reeds.

The space behind the reeds was a small, secluded clearing. And it was here that he saw the first sign of the Clay-Fingers. Dotted around the clearing, half-buried in the soft, dark earth, were dozens of small, fired clay objects. They were not shards or broken pieces. Some were perfect spheres, others twisted into elegant, abstract spirals, and some were shaped like the fossilised ammonites he sometimes found on the beach. They were markers, signposts, a form of art that was also a language. He picked up one of the spheres. It was smooth and cool, and it fit perfectly in the palm of his hand, its weight comforting and solid. It felt ancient, imbued with a deep, quiet patience. He looked up from the clay sphere and saw the entrance. It was so perfectly integrated into the bank that he had almost missed it. Not a door, but a low, wide archway, the clay of the bank smoothed and shaped, reinforced with a lattice of woven willow branches. The structure seemed less to have been built than to have been grown, persuaded to exist by gentle, knowing hands. A tiny, almost invisible wisp of pale smoke, smelling not of coal and malice but of charcoal and baking earth, drifted from a cleverly disguised vent somewhere above the arch.

Flinch stopped. He was an intruder here, reeking of the city’s underbelly, his soul still stained with the fire and violence of the vaults. He remembered his approach to Silt’s barricade, the offering of bacon fat, the silent wait. These goblins were different. They were potters, shapers of the earth. A tribute of scavenged food would be an insult. They would value what was made, not what was found. He stood for a long moment, then slowly, deliberately, he sank to his knees in the soft, loamy soil just before the archway. Pip, seeming to understand the gravity of the moment, lay down quietly beside him. From a deep pocket in his ragged jacket, Flinch retrieved his last link to his old life: the coil of fine, pliable wire. He didn’t look at the entrance. He focused his entire being on the task at hand. His long, nimble fingers, still raw and scarred, began to work, bending and twisting the metal with a familiarity that was as natural as breathing. He was not making a fixing, not this time. He was shaping a thought. He wove the wire into the form of a bird, a small, intricate creature with delicate, outstretched wings and a slender, hopeful beak. It was a shore-bird, a sandpiper, a creature of the liminal space between land and sea, a fitting symbol for a goblin caught between two worlds. When he was done, he held it out in his open palm, an offering from one maker to another, a silent, desperate plea: *I am not a warrior. I am a mender. I am lost.*

The sun was a red smear on the horizon, and the shadows in the clearing were growing long and deep when a figure finally emerged from the low, dark archway. It was a goblin, but a creature so different from the sharp, furtive city-dwellers that she might have been another species entirely. She was short and broad, built of the same stuff as the riverbank itself, her movements slow and deliberate. Her skin was the colour of wet grey clay, and her hands, visible below the cuffs of her simple homespun tunic, were stained dark with it. Her hair was a tangled mat of grey and white, like the roots of an ancient tree, and her face was a landscape of deep, placid wrinkles. She carried no weapon. Her eyes, dark and calm as a deep pool of water, took in the scene: the exhausted, grimy goblin, the equally filthy dog, and the offering held out on a trembling hand. Her gaze lingered on the delicate wire sandpiper, and for a long, silent moment, the world seemed to hold its breath. Her expression was utterly unreadable, a mask of ancient, earthy patience. Then, she spoke, her voice not the rasp of a city-goblin or the hiss of a warrior, but a low, soft sound, like mud shifting at the bottom of a river. "You have brought metal into the clay-lands," she said, and it was impossible to tell if it was an observation, an accusation, or a sentence.

The old goblin’s voice, a low rumble like stones shifting in a riverbed, hung in the cooling air. It was not a question, nor was it a threat. It was a simple, profound statement of fact, a geological observation that defined the chasm between their two worlds. Flinch’s hand, holding the delicate wire sandpiper, remained outstretched, a fragile bridge across that chasm. He could not speak. His throat was a knot of mud and exhaustion. He could only kneel, a supplicant from a world of rust and ruin, offering his small, metallic soul to a creature of the patient earth. The goblin elder, Vetch, took a slow step forward, her bare, clay-caked feet making no sound on the soft ground. Her dark, placid eyes did not look at Flinch’s face, with its brand of fire and its mask of grime, but at the offering in his hand.

She did not take it immediately. For a long moment, she simply looked, her gaze taking in the intricate weave of the wings, the hopeful tilt of the head, the sheer, impossible delicacy of the form he had coaxed from a piece of scavenged junk. Then, slowly, she reached out. Her hand was broad and powerful, her fingers blunt, the nails packed with the dark grey clay that was her medium. Her touch was surprisingly gentle as her fingers closed not on the bird, but on Flinch’s own hand beneath it. Her skin was cool and smooth, like a river stone. She lifted his hand, bringing the wire bird closer to her ancient face, her eyes narrowing as she studied its construction, the way the light caught on the twisted metal. "You have a maker’s hands," she said, her low voice softer now. "Though they are trained to a hard song. The salt sighs louder now. The tide is not a patient guest. You cannot stay on the mud." With that, she gently took the wire bird from his palm, her fingers closing around its fragile form, and turned, a silent command for him to follow.

Flinch scrambled to his feet, a wave of light-headed relief making the world swim before his eyes. He motioned for Pip, and together they followed the slow, deliberate figure of the elder through the low, arched entrance. The moment they stepped inside, the world changed. The vast, open emptiness of the mudflats was replaced by an intimate, enveloping sense of peace and enclosure. They were in a wide, circular chamber, its walls and ceiling not built but sculpted from the living clay of the riverbank, their surfaces smoothed and burnished to a soft, matte glow. The air was warm and smelled of damp earth, the clean smoke of a charcoal fire, and the unique, dusty scent of baking clay. A gentle, amber light came from several small, recessed niches where tallow lamps burned with a steady, smokeless flame. It was like stepping into the heart of a giant, hand-thrown pot.

Other goblins were here, perhaps a dozen of them, all shaped from the same earthy mould as Vetch. They were gathered in small groups, their movements unhurried and rhythmic. Some sat before simple, foot-powered potter's wheels, their hands slick with wet clay, coaxing bowls and jars into existence with a silent, focused grace. Others were decorating unfired pots with intricate patterns using sharpened sticks. No one spoke. The only sounds were the soft whir of the wheels, the gentle scrape of wood on clay, and the crackle of a low fire in a great, beehive-shaped kiln that dominated the far side of the chamber, its sealed entrance radiating a powerful, dry heat. As Flinch and Pip entered, every head turned, every pair of dark, placid eyes fixing on them. The whirring of the wheels slowed and stopped. The silence that fell was not hostile, but one of profound, bottomless curiosity. They were looking at Flinch as if he were a creature from a myth, a visitor from a loud, fast, angry world they had only heard of in stories.

Vetch led him to a quiet corner, away from the central hearth, and gestured to a low, woven reed mat on the floor. "Sit," she commanded softly. "The water-bringer will come." Flinch collapsed onto the mat, his aching body screaming its gratitude. Pip, after a moment’s hesitation, lay down beside him, his head on his paws, his watchful eyes tracking the slow, silent movements of the Clay-Fingers. A young goblin with a kind, open face brought them a shallow clay bowl of cool, fresh water and another containing a thick, savoury-smelling mushroom broth. Flinch drank greedily, the clean water a balm to his raw throat, and then shared the broth with Pip, who lapped it up with grateful, slurping sounds that seemed sacrilegiously loud in the quiet chamber. Vetch stood before them, holding the wire bird in her palm, waiting with a patience that seemed carved from stone.

When the bowls were empty, she finally spoke again. "The world screamed, two nights past," she said, her voice a low murmur. "The deep earth shuddered, and the water in the old channels ran black with the dust of a great collapse. It is the reason you are here." It was not a question. Flinch looked up at her, at the calm, knowing certainty in her ancient eyes, and understood that there was no point in evasion. "I was there," he croaked, his voice still hoarse. "I was in the place that fell." He paused, gathering his strength, his courage. "I am being hunted. Not for what I did, but for what I now carry." He reached into his battered scavenging bag, his fingers closing around the familiar, heavy rectangle of Silt’s book. He pulled it out, its oilcloth wrapping seeming crude and foul in this clean, earthy space. He unwrapped it and held it out, not as an offering this time, but as evidence, as the source of all his trouble.

Vetch’s placid expression flickered. A deep, ancient sorrow passed through her eyes as she looked at the book. She did not take it. "The Archive of the Deep," she breathed, the name a half-forgotten legend on her tongue. "We felt his passing. The Keeper of the Underbelly is gone, and his secrets are unmoored, a flood looking for a new course." She looked from the book back to Flinch. "You are not a warrior. The scorch on your face is a brand, not a battle-scar. But you carry a weight far heavier than any spear. Why bring this poison to our door?" The question was gentle, but it held the weight of her entire clan’s survival.

"Because I am a mender, not a keeper of secrets," Flinch said, his voice gaining a desperate strength. "I fix what is broken. This... this is a breaking of the whole world, a secret I cannot fix and dare not carry alone. Silt’s book says you are a people of peace, of making. I hoped… I hoped you would grant me sanctuary. A place to hide. A place to be quiet." The plea hung in the warm, silent air. Vetch considered him for a long time, her gaze seeming to penetrate the layers of his filth and fear, seeking the goblin underneath.

"Sanctuary is not a thing that is given freely," she said at last. "It is earned. It must be woven into the fabric of the community. We are a people of clay. Our world is soft, and slow, and patient. Your world is hard, and fast, and sharp. Your very essence is a discord here." She held up the wire sandpiper. "This is a beautiful thing. It has spirit. But it is metal. It will not break. It will not return to the earth. It will endure, unchanged, long after the hands that made it are dust. We have such a thing in our home. A metal sickness. A piece of the human world that has poisoned our water and defied our hands for generations. It is a thing we do not understand." She fixed him with a gaze that was both a challenge and a lifeline. "You are a mender of the hard world. If you want a place among the soft, you will fix our sickness. That is the price."

The weight of the challenge settled on Flinch, heavy and real, but it was a different kind of weight from the suffocating dread he had carried from the ruins of the vaults. This was the solid, understandable weight of a problem to be solved, a machine to be mended. It was a language he understood. He looked from Vetch’s ancient, patient face to the delicate wire bird she held, a fragile piece of his own hard world now entrusted to the soft. There was no choice, and for the first time in what felt like a lifetime, the lack of choice was a comfort, a firm path opening in a world that had become a trackless swamp of fear. He gave a single, sharp nod, the most solemn oath he could offer. He was a mender. He would mend.

Vetch seemed to accept his silent vow. Her expression did not change, but a subtle shift in the air, a collective exhalation from the other watching goblins, told him that a contract had been sealed. She placed the wire sandpiper on a small, fire-blackened stone near the central kiln, its metallic form a stark and alien accent in the earthy tableau. It was a placeholder, a promise, a hostage. Vetch then beckoned to one of the younger potters, a goblin with long, dextrous fingers and a quiet, watchful demeanor. “Loam will guide you,” she said to Flinch, her voice once again a low rumble. “He will show you the sickness. Observe. Understand. Then you will tell us if your hard-world song can sing a cure.” Loam gave a slight bow of his head and turned, his eyes flickering from Flinch to Pip with a cautious curiosity that was leagues away from the open hostility of the pier-goblins. Flinch rose on aching legs, beckoned to Pip, and followed his new guide away from the warmth of the kiln and deeper into the living earth.

Their path was not a tunnel in the way Flinch understood it, not a brick-lined, uniform tube built for a single purpose. It was a winding, organic passage that seemed to follow the natural contours of the deep clay, its walls undulating and smooth, punctuated by the ghostly white fingers of ancient tree roots that had pierced the earth from the world above. They passed side chambers that served as sleeping burrows, each containing little more than a pile of woven reed mats, and storerooms where unfired pots were stacked in silent, waiting ranks. The air grew cooler as they moved away from the main chamber, and a new scent began to thread its way through the clean, earthy smell. It was a sharp, metallic tang, underscored by a cloying, sickly-sweetness that reminded Flinch of the leaking batteries he sometimes scavenged. It was the smell of poison. Pip, trotting close at Flinch’s heel, let out a low, unhappy whine, his nose twitching in distress. They were getting close.

Loam stopped at the entrance to a small, self-contained cavern, his hand held up in a gesture of caution. The sickness was here. The chamber was a place of profound wrongness, a wound in the heart of the Clay-Fingers' home. In the center of the space was a deep, natural basin that should have held clear, fresh water, the source from which the entire warren drank. Instead, the pool was dark and stagnant, its surface filmed with a shimmering, rainbow-slick of chemical iridescence. From the center of the pool rose a monstrous shape of metal, a huge, cylindrical object of corroded copper and weeping, rust-pocked iron, half-buried in the clay floor of the basin. It looked like a section of a vast, forgotten machine, something torn from the guts of a human factory or a warship and left to die here generations ago. The clay around the pool was stained a sickly, sterile grey, and nothing grew. The air was thick with the chemical stench, a smell that made Flinch’s eyes water and his throat tighten.

Flinch stepped past Loam into the diseased chamber, his scavenger’s mind clicking into a familiar, analytical rhythm that pushed his fear to the background. Loam and a few other goblins who had followed them hung back, their faces grim, watching him as if he were a shaman about to perform a dangerous and incomprehensible ritual. Flinch walked slowly around the edge of the tainted pool, his eyes taking in every detail of the metal behemoth. He saw the massive, verdigris-streaked copper casing, the iron support bands eaten through with rust, the strange, unreadable stenciled numbers and letters still faintly visible on one side. This was old, he realized. Old-world human, from one of their great wars, perhaps. It was a thing of power, but its power was now the slow, inexorable power of decay. He knelt at the water's edge, ignoring the stench, and looked at the way the oily film emanated from a series of weeping seams near the object's base. The sickness had a source.

With a deep breath, he waded into the shallow, tainted pool, the cold, greasy water swirling around his ankles. Pip whined in protest from the bank, but stayed where he was. The Clay-Fingers murmured among themselves, their placid faces showing flickers of alarm. Flinch ignored them all. He ran his long, sensitive fingers over the corroded metal, feeling the texture of the rust, the pitted surface of the copper. He found what he was looking for: a maintenance hatch, its bolts fused solid by decades of corrosion. The Clay-Fingers had tried their own solution; he could see where they had attempted to plaster the weeping seams with thick layers of clay, a desperate poultice on a mortal wound. But the poison was too aggressive, too alien. It had simply seeped through, turning their sacred earth into sterile sludge. He pulled out his multi-tool, selecting a hardened steel pick. He began to scrape at the fused edge of the hatch, the sharp scratch of metal on metal a profane sound in this quiet place. With a grunt of effort, he managed to get the pick into the seam and lever it. A thin, dark, foul-smelling liquid, thicker than the water, oozed from the new opening. The machine was bleeding its guts out.

Flinch retreated from the pool, his mind racing, piecing together the clues. He wiped his greasy hands on his trousers and turned to Loam. “It is a filter,” he said, his voice raw but certain. “A human machine, for cleaning water or fuel. But it is old, and the cleaning materials inside—the chemicals, the metals—they have rotted. The machine’s skin is breaking, and its rotten insides are bleeding into your spring.” He looked at the concerned faces of the goblins. “Your clay cannot stop it. The poison must be cut out, or the wound sealed from the inside. I would have to open it. It will be dangerous. The bleeding will get worse before it gets better.” Loam translated Flinch's words into a series of low, guttural sounds for the others, who listened intently, their dark eyes fixed on the grimy, determined goblin from the hard world.

There was a long, silent conference, then Loam turned back to Flinch. "Vetch has been told. Her wisdom is that the sickness is already killing us slowly. A faster danger is a risk worth taking." His face was grim, but his eyes held a new respect. "You have earned your rest. For tonight, you are a guest. Tomorrow, you will be a surgeon." He led Flinch and Pip from the poisoned chamber to a small, private burrow, a simple, clean alcove carved from the earth, containing nothing but a fresh reed mat and a bowl of water. It was a cell, but it was a haven. For the first time in days, Flinch was in a space where he was not being hunted, where a door was not a point of terror but a boundary of peace. He sank onto the mat, every muscle, every bone, every nerve sighing with a relief so profound it was almost painful.

Later, as Pip slept in a twitching, dreaming heap beside him, Flinch could not find his own rest. The weight of his new task was a familiar pressure, a problem to be turned over and over in his mind. But this was a problem with missing pieces. He did not have the tools, the materials, he would need to perform the surgery. He would have to improvise, to make what he needed. His mind, trained in the art of finding value in the discarded, began to catalogue the possibilities. He thought of the iron bands on the machine itself, of scavengeable parts, of the properties of fire and clay. He was a mender without his workshop. He reached into his sack and pulled out Silt's book. He had no expectation of finding a manual for repairing ancient human water filters, but knowledge was a tool like any other. He opened the heavy volume, not to the maps of the underbelly or the genealogies of the lost, but to a section near the back he had only glanced at before. It was titled 'An Unreliable Bestiary of Sun-Walker Detritus.' He began to read, his eyes scanning Silt's spidery, cynical notes on the foolish, dangerous, and sometimes useful things the human world left behind, searching for a clue, for a forgotten scrap of knowledge that might help him fix a sickness at the heart of the world.

The book was not a manual; it was a post-mortem. Silt had dissected the human world with the cold, detached curiosity of a coroner examining a diseased corpse. The section on ‘Sun-Walker Detritus’ was a litany of cynical poetry. He wrote of ‘The Glass Eye’, describing windows not as things to see through, but as brittle, silent observers that shattered into a thousand sharp memories. He described ‘The Black Veins’, the insulated electrical cables that snaked through the city’s walls, as sleeping serpents that could wake with a bite of furious, artificial lightning. Flinch’s eyes scanned the spidery script, his mind absorbing Silt’s worldview, a philosophy of pure, unadulterated pragmatism. The old goblin saw everything in terms of its potential danger, its method of decay, and its use after its primary function had failed. It was a scavenger’s bible.

He found an entry that made him stop, his finger tracing the words. It was titled ‘The Patient Poison of Sealed Tins’. Silt described the canned foods of the humans, marveling at the hubris of trapping organic matter in a thin metal skin and expecting it to last forever. ‘The rot,’ he had written, ‘does not die. It simply sleeps. Given a century in the dark and damp, the metal skin will tire. The rot will wake, and it will eat its way out, a slow, determined poison that remembers its imprisonment.’ A little further on, another entry caught his eye, this one on ceramics. Silt was dismissive. ‘The Pot-People’s fancy mud,’ he called it. ‘Brittle. Useless for mending. But it has one virtue the hard world lacks. When it is kissed by the Great Fire, its skin closes forever. It becomes stone. It can hold a liquid without complaint, without tiring, without thought. It is a perfect prison.’ Flinch stared at the two entries, his mind a whirring collection of gears clicking into place. A sleeping rot in a tiring metal skin. A perfect prison of fire-kissed stone. The two disparate observations collided in his brain, and in their fusion, an idea sparked, a plan so simple, so elegant, and so deeply rooted in the two worlds he now straddled, that he knew it was the only answer.

Sleep, when it finally came, was deep and dreamless, a black, velvet oblivion. He woke to the faint sound of soft, rhythmic scraping from the main chamber and the gentle pressure of Pip’s head on his chest. For the first time in days, he felt not the gnawing anxiety of a fugitive or the hollow ache of a survivor, but the familiar, clear-headed focus of a mender with a schematic in his head. He left his burrow and found Loam, his hands already grey with wet clay, working at a wheel near the great kiln. The young potter looked up, his movements ceasing, his dark eyes questioning. Flinch did not have the words of the Clay-Fingers, but he had the universal language of making. He gestured for Loam to follow him, and led him not to the poisoned spring, but to the shelves of unfired pots. He picked up a simple, wide-mouthed jar, its clay still soft and damp.

"This is the sickness," Flinch said, his voice quiet but firm, holding up the jar. He pointed to the metal machine in the diseased chamber. "The metal skin is a bad pot. Old. Tired. It has a crack." He then pointed to a hairline fracture in a different, discarded piece of pottery. "You cannot patch the outside. The poison inside is too strong. It will always find a way through." Loam nodded slowly, his eyes wide with understanding. He followed the analogy completely. "We have to open the bad pot," Flinch continued, his hands mimicking the prying of a lid. "We must scoop out all the rotten clay from inside." He made a scooping gesture. "But we cannot throw it on the ground. It would poison everything." He paused, letting the problem settle in the air between them. "So," he said, and his gaze swept across the rows of waiting, un-fired vessels, "you will make me new pots. The strongest you can make. Jars with thick walls and heavy lids. Sarcophagi. We will put the rotten clay inside these new pots, seal them, and give them to the Great Fire." He pointed to the kiln, its sealed entrance radiating a heat that was both creative and destructive. "Silt called it a perfect prison. We will make a prison for the poison, and your fire will be the lock and key."

Loam stared at him, his mouth slightly agape. A slow smile spread across his face, a dawning of pure, intellectual delight that transcended the language barrier. He understood. It was a plan that honoured their craft, that used their deepest magic—the transformative power of fire on clay—to solve a problem of the hard, metal world. It was a harmony of two different songs. He spoke quickly, excitedly, to the other potters who had gathered to listen, his hands shaping the air, mimicking Flinch’s gestures, translating not just the words but the beautiful, simple elegance of the concept. A murmur of approval, of understanding, rippled through the gathered Clay-Fingers. For the first time since he had arrived, Flinch felt their placid curiosity shift into something warmer, something that felt almost like acceptance. He was no longer just a grimy outcast with a dangerous book; he was a mender with a good idea.

The warren transformed from a place of quiet, contemplative art into a workshop of focused, urgent industry. Under Flinch's nervous direction, and with Loam acting as his foreman and translator, the Clay-Fingers set to work. The best, most experienced potters were tasked with creating the sarcophagi: great, heavy-bellied jars, half as tall as Flinch, with thick, sturdy walls and lids designed to fit with a potter’s precision. Others began to prepare the kiln, stoking its fires with charcoal and dried peat, bringing its internal temperature slowly, carefully, up to the ferocious heat needed for vitrification. Flinch, meanwhile, worked with a different team, improvising the tools he would need for the surgery. He had them find the hardest, most thoroughly-fired shards of broken pottery from their waste pile, and he showed them how to grind the edges against sandstone blocks to create sharp, ceramic scrapers, tools that would not react to the chemicals inside the machine. They wove the thick, fibrous roots that hung from the ceilings into strong, durable ropes. His greatest challenge was finding a way to open the hatch. He needed leverage, something the soft world of clay and wood could not provide.

His solution came from the sickness itself. With Loam at his side, he returned to the poisoned chamber and pointed to the heavy, rust-eaten iron bands that girdled the copper cylinder. “I need these,” he explained. He showed Loam how, with careful, patient work using hammers made of solid, fire-hardened clay and wedges of sharp flint, they could attack the corroded bolts that held the bands in place. It was slow, brutal, exhausting work, a noisy and violent intrusion into the warren's quiet rhythms. But the Clay-Fingers, now invested in the plan, worked with a grim determination, their powerful, rhythmic blows echoing the hammer-falls of Grolnok's forges, but in the service of healing, not destruction. By nightfall, they had succeeded in freeing two long, heavy sections of iron. Under Flinch’s guidance, they heated the middle of one bar in the fierce outer embers of the kiln until it glowed a dull, angry red, and then, using stone hammers, they bent it into a massive crowbar. They had turned a piece of the disease into its own cure.

The next morning, a strange, tense silence fell over the warren. The sarcophagi stood in a stoic row, their clay still damp and grey. The kiln radiated a shimmering, almost unbearable heat. The final preparations were made. Flinch stood at the edge of the tainted pool, his improvised crowbar in his hand, a team of the strongest potters behind him holding the vine ropes and ceramic scrapers. Loam stood beside him, his face set with a mixture of fear and resolve. Vetch emerged from the main chamber and approached them, her slow, deliberate steps a calming influence on the palpable tension. She did not speak to Flinch, but placed a hand on Loam’s shoulder, a silent blessing. Then she looked at Flinch, and for the first time, he saw a flicker of something beyond her earthy patience in her ancient eyes: a fragile shard of hope. He gave a sharp, determined nod, turned to face the monolithic, weeping machine, and took a deep, steadying breath. The air stank of rot and metal. It was the smell of a hard-world sickness. And with a grunt of effort that echoed in the silent, waiting chamber, the mender from the city of iron and rust began his work.

The heavy iron crowbar was an ugly, brutal thing in Flinch's hands, a shard of the hard world he had brought into this quiet, earthy sanctuary. He jammed its flattened, heated tip into the fused seam of the maintenance hatch, the jarring scrape of metal on metal a desecration in the waiting silence. He grunted, putting his shoulder into it, his muscles screaming in protest. Behind him, he heard the creak and strain of the vine ropes as Loam and two of the strongest potters took up the slack, their bare feet finding purchase on the slippery clay floor. “Now!” Flinch yelled, and with a collective, guttural heave, they threw their weight against it. For a heart-stopping moment, nothing happened. Then, with a deep, groaning shriek of tortured metal, the corroded bolts tore free from their moorings. The hatch, with a final, sickening pop, blew inwards, and a wave of concentrated foulness, a stench a hundred times worse than the ambient stink of the chamber, billowed out in a visible, shimmering cloud. The Clay-Fingers cried out, stumbling back, their hands flying to their faces, but Flinch stood his ground, his senses already deadened by a lifetime of crawling through the city's foulest corners. The surgery had begun, and the patient was open on the table.

Stepping closer, his eyes watering, Flinch peered into the dark, weeping cavity. It was a cross-section of a century of industrial decay. The interior of the machine was not just filled with liquid; it was a layered nightmare of rotted components. He could see what looked like thick, fibrous pads, probably the original filters, now decomposed into a black, pulpy sludge. Between these layers were strange, crystalline growths, some a sickly, iridescent green, others a rusty, blood-red, that had formed as different chemicals had leached out and reacted with each other over the decades. At the very bottom lay a deep reservoir of the black, oily liquid that was the primary source of the poison, thick and viscous as tar. It was a terrarium of filth, a sealed ecosystem of rot that had finally eaten its way free. For all its horror, Flinch felt a surge of grim, professional satisfaction. The problem was no longer a mystery. It was simply a mess, and messes could be cleaned.

“The scrapers,” Flinch commanded, his voice tight. “Start with the top layers. Slow and steady.” Loam and his team moved forward, their earlier revulsion replaced by a grim determination. They wielded the sharp-edged ceramic scrapers with a surprising deftness, their potters’ hands, accustomed to shaping and carving clay, proving to be perfectly suited to the task of dissecting the machine’s rotten guts. The sound that filled the chamber was a stomach-turning symphony of wet, squelching noises as they pulled out great, dripping handfuls of the fibrous sludge and decaying crystals. Another team stood ready with the sarcophagi, their wide mouths waiting. Each time a load of the toxic waste was scraped free, it was carefully, almost reverently, transferred into one of the great clay jars. Flinch directed the operation like a frantic orchestra conductor, pointing out the next section to be cleared, warning them away from a patch of particularly nasty-looking crystals, his mind wholly consumed by the intricate, disgusting work. At the edge of the chamber, Pip lay with his nose buried under his paws, a small, miserable spectator to a horror his clean, sun-world soul could barely comprehend.

They had cleared half the machine when the crisis came. As Loam scraped at a deep, compressed layer of sludge, he uncovered a pocket of a different substance, a thick, translucent gel that pulsed with a faint, internal light. The moment the air touched it, the gel began to hiss, releasing a thin, acrid smoke and eating into the vitrified edge of Loam's ceramic scraper with a furious fizzing sound. A spiderweb of cracks spread across the tool, and with a sharp snap, the end broke off, falling into the toxic mire. Loam cried out, leaping back as if he’d been burned, his eyes wide with alarm. Panic flickered through the assembled goblins. This was a new kind of poison, an active and aggressive demon in the heart of the rot. “Clay dust!” Flinch yelled, his mind racing back to a passage in Silt’s book about neutralizing acidic human concoctions. “Dry dust! Now!” Another goblin, reacting instantly, scooped up a handful of fine, powdered clay from a nearby bin and flung it onto the hissing gel. The effect was immediate. The dust absorbed the substance, smothering its reaction, turning the aggressive gel into a thick, inert clod of paste. The hissing stopped. The chamber was silent for a tense moment, and then Loam looked at Flinch, his expression a mixture of terror and profound gratitude. The immediate danger had passed, but the incident served as a stark reminder of the unknown poisons they were dealing with.

The work continued with a new, heightened sense of caution. The remaining sludge and crystals were removed with painstaking care, each scoopful examined before it was transferred to the sarcophagi. Finally, only the deep reservoir of black, oily liquid remained. Using smaller pots as bailers, tied to the ends of vine ropes, they began the slow, laborious process of emptying the machine’s foul heart. The liquid was thick and heavy, and it clung to everything it touched, staining the ceramic bailers a permanent, greasy black. It took hours, but at last, the final dregs were scooped out. The machine, for the first time in generations, was an empty, silent, hollowed-out husk, its power to harm finally excised. Flinch stood before it, dripping with sweat and filth, his body screaming with exhaustion, and felt a quiet, fierce pride. He looked at the row of eight great sarcophagi, now filled with the contained sickness, their gaping mouths awaiting their final seal.

The final stage of the burial was a solemn ritual. With the last of the poison safely entombed, Loam and the other master potters came forward. Their hands, once tools of dissection, became instruments of creation again. They took up balls of fresh, wet clay and, with slow, practiced movements, they began to apply it to the rims of the great jars and the undersides of the heavy lids. One by one, the lids were lowered into place, and the seams were smoothed and sealed, each motion a deliberate and prayerful act. There was no room for error. The prisons had to be perfect. Flinch stood back, a filthy, exhausted observer, watching as the Clay-Fingers reclaimed the work, turning his brutal surgery into a sacred act of healing. When the last sarcophagus was sealed, a quiet sigh of collective relief passed through the assembled goblins. The poison was contained. Now, it had to be unmade.

The procession from the poisoned chamber to the main hall was slow and heavy with the weight of their accomplishment. It took the strength of six goblins, using wide slings of woven fibre, to move each sarcophagus. They carried their burdens with a grim, triumphant reverence, their path lit by goblins holding tallow lamps. They were pallbearers at the funeral of their own sickness. In the main chamber, the great kiln was no longer just a source of warmth; it was a roaring, breathing monster, the heat from its clay-plugged door a solid wall of force. Vetch was waiting for them, her face impassive, but her dark eyes held the fierce glow of the fire. At her silent command, two goblins, their faces shielded by wet cloths, used long iron poles—the scavenged mates to Flinch’s crowbar—to pry the great clay plug from the kiln’s mouth.

A wave of pure, white-hot light and heat blasted out, forcing everyone back. The inside of the kiln was not red or orange; it was a blinding, incandescent white, the colour of the sun’s core. The heat was so intense it seemed to vaporize the very air, creating shimmering, liquid distortions around the kiln’s mouth. This was the Great Fire, and Flinch felt a primal, instinctual awe that dwarfed anything he had felt in the face of Grolnok’s machine. One by one, with an immense, coordinated effort, the sarcophagi were pushed on clay rollers up to the edge of the inferno and then tipped inside, vanishing into the white-hot glare. When the last of the eight jars had been consumed by the fire, the great plug was shoved back into place and sealed with wet clay, which hissed and steamed, baking hard in seconds. The prison was locked. The sentence had begun.

A profound silence descended upon the great chamber, broken only by the low, hungry roar of the contained fire. The work was done. The tension that had held the warren in its grip for two days finally broke, and a wave of bone-deep exhaustion washed over everyone. Flinch felt as if the strings holding his own limbs together had been cut. He leaned against a cool clay wall, his body trembling with fatigue, and slid to the floor. He looked at his hands, caked in a mixture of grease, poison, and the sacred clay of his hosts. They were the hands of a mender, but they had performed a task he had never imagined. He had not just fixed a broken thing; he had participated in a magic that was deep, and slow, and utterly real. His gaze travelled to the small, fire-blackened stone where his delicate wire sandpiper still stood, a tiny, metallic testament to his arrival. He had come as a fugitive from a world of hard edges and fast violence. He had earned his sanctuary, for now, not with a weapon, but with his hands, his head, and a half-remembered passage from a dead goblin’s book. The fire roared, and for the first time in a very long time, Flinch Underbellow felt the quiet, steady warmth of a home that was not his own.
